newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian trade sees pullback in sizzling coffee rally.
newsitem.headline: Asian trade sees pullback in sizzling coffee rally.

text.p: The sizzling rally in world coffee prices appears overdone and London robusta futures were expected to retreat by between US$50 and $130 a tonne on profit-taking, Asian traders said on Thursday.
They New York arabica prices were expected to follow suit in profit-taking later in the day, they said.
"The rally is way too much overdone. It's due $120 down," the chief coffee dealer for a U.S. commodity trading house said.
Another trader for a European commodity house said: "Nothing lasts forever. We should see it go down about $55-$130."
Very tight supplies of coffee in Latin America and low stocks in consuming countries have sparked the rally.
London's benchmark May robusta contract soared on Wednesday to a new nine-month high of $1,820 a tonne before late profit-taking knocked it back down to $1,780, up $82 on the day.
New York May rallied to a 2-1/2 year peak at 209.50 U.S. cents a lb prior to settling at 200.65 cents.
U.S. coffee prices have now gained 30 cents, or 17 percent, over the last four days.

"Some sort of correction is reasonable to expect," a European trader said, adding that the pattern of "forced liquidation" seen in New York and London towards the end of trading on Wednesday may again be seen later on Thursday.
"New York went up much faster than London so New York will go down much faster than London," another dealer said.
Some speculative fund managers appear to have decided to decide to cash in their profits, one trader said.
"At a certain stage, one guy said 'I have a nice profit, I'll take my profits.' The next guy decided to take their profits and this seems to have spread," he said.
Some traders said any correction may be mild and short-lived as the bullish fundamentals of the coffee market remained intact.
"We still have the same huge shortage of coffee coming up over the next 1-1/2 years," one dealer said.
"I wouldn't count on a big correction, the way the market has been behaving the past few days," another coffee trader said.
